The '''American Rescue Plan Act of 2021''', also called the '''COVID-19 Stimulus Package''' or '''American Rescue Plan''', is a {{US$|1.9 trillion}} [[Stimulus (economics)|economic stimulus]] bill passed by the [[117th United States Congress]] and signed into law by [[President of the United States|President]] [[Joe Biden]] on March 11, 2021, to speed up the country's recovery from the [[Economic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States|economic]] and health effects of the [[COVID-19 pandemic in the United States|COVID-19 pandemic]] and  [[COVID-19 recession#United States|recession]].<ref>{{Cite web |date=January 15, 2021 |title=American Rescue Plan: Inside Biden's $1.9 Trillion Stimulus |url=https://smartasset.com/financial-advisor/american-rescue-plan-biden-third-stimulus |access-date=January 16, 2021 |website=SmartAsset |language=en}}[https://www.disasterloanadvisors.com/erc/]</ref> First proposed on January 14, 2021, the package builds upon many of the measures in the [[CARES Act]] from March 2020 and in the [[Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2021]], from December.<ref>{{Cite web |last1=Luhby |first1=Tami |last2=Lobosco |first2=Katie |date=January 14, 2021 |title=Here's what's in Biden's $1.9 trillion economic rescue package |url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/01/14/politics/biden-economic-rescue-package-coronavirus-stimulus/index.html |access-date=January 16, 2021 |website=CNN}}</ref><ref name="Tankersley 2021">{{Cite news |last1=Tankersley |first1=Jim |last2=Crowley |first2=Michael |date=January 14, 2021 |title=Here are the highlights of Biden's $1.9 trillion 'American Rescue Plan.' |language=en-US |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/14/us/biden-american-rescue-plan.html |access-date=January 16, 2021 |issn=0362-4331}}</ref>

On February 8, 2021, the [[United States House Committee on Financial Services|Financial Services]] and [[United States House Committee on Education and Labor|Education and Labor]] committees released a draft of $1.9 trillion stimulus legislation. A portion of the relief package was approved by the [[United States House Committee on Ways and Means|House Ways and Means]] on February 11, setting it up for a vote in the House. The legislation was also approved by the [[United States House Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure|Transportation and Infrastructure]], [[United States House Committee on Small Business|Small Business]], and [[United States House Committee on Veterans' Affairs|House Veterans Affairs]] committees. On February 22, the [[United States House Committee on the Budget|House Budget Committee]] voted 19–16 to advance the bill to the House for a floor vote.<ref>{{Cite web|first1=Lauren|last1=Fox|first2=Annie|last2=Grayer|title=House panel sets up floor vote on Covid relief bill later this week|url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/02/22/politics/covid-19-relief-bill-committee-advance/index.html|access-date=March 6, 2021|website=CNN|date=February 22, 2021 }}</ref> The bill passed the House by a vote of 219–212 on February 27. All but two Democrats voted for the bill and all Republicans voted against the bill.<ref>{{Cite web|last1=Segers|first1=Grace|title=Biden's $1.9 trillion relief bill passes House, but faces Senate hurdle|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/covid-relief-bill-american-rescue-plan-house-vote-today/|access-date=February 27, 2021|website=CBS News|date=February 27, 2021 |language=en-US}}</ref> A modified version passed the Senate on March 6 by a vote of 50–49.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Behrmann|first=Ledyard King, Bart Jansen, Nicholas Wu and Savannah|title=Senate passes Biden's COVID relief bill, sending legislation with $1,400 stimulus checks to House|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2021/03/06/bidens-covid-stimulus-bill-passes-senate-legislation-heads-house/6886446002/|access-date=March 6, 2021|website=USA TODAY|language=en-US}}</ref> The final amended bill was passed by the House on March 10 by a vote of 220–211 with one Democrat ([[Jared Golden]]) voting against it alongside all Republicans.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Hagen|first=Lisa|title=House Passes Amended Coronavirus Relief Bill, Delivers Biden First Legislative Victory|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/politics/articles/2021-03-10/house-passes-amended-coronavirus-relief-bill-delivers-biden-first-legislative-victory/|access-date=March 10, 2021|website=U.S. News & World Report|language=en-US}}</ref> The bill was signed into law by President Biden on March 11, 2021.<ref name="Segers 2021">{{Cite web|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/biden-signs-covid-relief-bill-american-rescue-plan-into-law/|title=Biden signs $1.9 trillion COVID relief bill, American Rescue Plan, into law|date=March 12, 2021|website=www.cbsnews.com |last=Segers |first=Grace}}</ref>

The American Rescue Plan Act provided for direct economic stimulus payments to individual taxpayers with incomes of $75,000 or less. The Act also allocated $350 billion in assistance to state and local governments, $14 billion for [[COVID-19 vaccine]] distribution, and $130 billion to schools to help them safely re-open for in-person instruction. The Act included $300 billion in unemployment benefits that were scheduled to extend through Labor Day 2021, as well as an expanded child tax credit. In addition, the Act called for the distribution of $50 billion to small businesses and another $25 billion for relief for small and mid-sized restaurants. The Act expanded eligibility for [[Affordable Care Act]] (ACA) subsidies and gave states incentives to expand Medicaid.<ref name="Segers 2021" />

==Background==
{{Joe Biden series|expanded=Policies}}

===Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic===
{{Further|Economic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States|COVID-19 pandemic in the United States}}By mid-2020, the United States was facing what the [[National Bureau of Economic Research]] determined was an economic recession,<ref>{{Cite news|last1=Rushe|first1=Dominic|title=US has officially entered first recession since 2009|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2020/jun/08/us-has-officially-entered-first-recession-since-2009|access-date=February 7, 2021|newspaper=The Guardian|language=en}}</ref> and by February 2021, 500,000 Americans had died of COVID-19.<ref>{{Cite web|last1=Ehley|first1=Brianna|title=U.S. surpasses 500,000 Covid deaths|url= https://www.politico.com/news/2021/02/22/us-500-000-covid-deaths-470927|access-date=February 22, 2021|website=Politico|date=February 22, 2021|language=en}}</ref> Over 29 million Americans had tested positive for [[COVID-19]] by March.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Dugan |first1=Kelli |title= Coronavirus: Total US COVID-19 cases top 29 million as death toll swells past 525,000 |url=https://www.kiro7.com/news/trending/coronavirus-total-us-covid-19-cases-top-29-million-death-toll-swells-past-525000/K3KQFU4ZWJGC3BRYWNTE252UEU/ |website=KIRO-TV |date=March 8, 2021}}</ref> The United States also faced eviction, unemployment, and hunger crises since the start of the pandemic.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Yurkevich |first1=Vanessa |title=Evictions, unemployment and hunger: The American economy Joe Biden inherits |url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/01/26/economy/evictions-unemployment-hunger-biden/index.html |website=CNN |date=January 26, 2021}}</ref> Over 30 to 40 million Americans faced a risk of being evicted from their homes by January 2021.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Hackney |first1=Suzette |title=Millions of Americans face eviction amid COVID-19: 'I have no idea what to do.' |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/opinion/2020/12/17/americans-fall-through-eviction-cracks-during-covid-19-crisis-column/6056483002/ |newspaper=USA Today |date=December 17, 2020}}</ref> Then-president [[Donald Trump]] also faced criticism for not having a federal strategy to combat the pandemic, such as nationwide mask mandates on transportation, a mass testing strategy, health guidelines, providing medical-grade protective gear, and having an effective vaccine distribution strategy. On January 20, the day after [[Joe Biden]] was [[Inauguration of Joe Biden|inaugurated]], he warned that the death toll could exceed 500,000.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Stolberg |first1=Sheryl |title=Biden Unveils National Strategy That Trump Resisted |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/21/us/politics/biden-coronavirus-response.html |newspaper=New York Times |date=January 21, 2021}}</ref> According to [[Snopes]], Biden inherited a vaccine distribution strategy from Trump, and disease expert [[Anthony Fauci]] said that his administration would incorporate some aspects of that Trump-era strategy in its ongoing work.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Lee |first1=Jessica |title=Did Biden Inherit 'Nonexistent' COVID-19 Vaccine Distribution Plan? |url=https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/vaccine-biden-trump/ |website=Snopes |date=January 22, 2021}}</ref>

===Previous COVID-19 pandemic legislation===
{{Further|U.S. federal government response to the COVID-19 pandemic|List of COVID-19 pandemic legislation}}Prior to the passing of the American Rescue Plan, the [[CARES Act]] and [[Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2021]] were signed into law by then-[[President of the United States|president]] [[Donald Trump]] in March and December 2020, respectively. Trump previously expressed support for direct payments of $2,000 along with [[Joe Biden]] and many [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrats]]. Even though Trump called for Congress to pass a bill increasing direct payments from $600 to $2,000, then-[[Senate Majority Leader]] [[Mitch McConnell]] blocked the effort.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Gregorian|first1=Dareh|date=December 29, 2020|title=McConnell blocks Senate Democrats' move to pass $2,000 coronavirus checks|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/congress/mcconnell-blocks-senate-democrats-move-pass-2-000-coronavirus-checks-n1252483|website=NBC News}}</ref> Additionally, the House voted on the [[HEROES Act]] in May 2020, which would operate as a $3 trillion relief package. Despite approval in the lower chambers, the Republican-led Senate would not consider such a bill, citing it to be "dead on arrival".<ref>{{Cite web|title=Republicans 'Appalled' By $3 Trillion Heroes Act As Democrats Urge Its Passing|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/sergeiklebnikov/2020/05/16/republicans-appalled-by-3-trillion-heroes-act-as-democrats-urge-its-passing/?sh=42e269327599|website=Forbes|language=en}}</ref> Prior to the [[2021 Georgia runoff election|Georgia Senate runoffs]]<!--intentional link to DAB page-->, Biden said that the direct payments of $2,000 would be passed only if Democratic candidates<!-- not Democratic nominees - Warnock-san's election was a jungle primary runoff which could in theory have featured two Democrats --> [[Jon Ossoff]] and [[Raphael Warnock]] won;<ref>{{cite web|last1=Duffy|first1=Kate|date=January 5, 2021|title=Biden tells Georgia voters that $2,000 stimulus checks will never arrive if Republicans win Senate runoffs|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/biden-georgia-senate-runoff-2000-stimulus-checks-immediately-2021-1|website=Business Insider}}</ref> the promise of comprehensive COVID-19 relief legislation was reported as a factor in their eventual victories.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.npr.org/2021/01/06/952417689/democrat-jon-ossoff-claims-victory-over-david-perdue-in-georgia-runoff |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210331164138/https://www.npr.org/2021/01/06/952417689/democrat-jon-ossoff-claims-victory-over-david-perdue-in-georgia-runoff |archive-date=March 31, 2021|title=Jon Ossoff Wins Georgia Runoff, Handing Democrats Senate Control : NPR |website=[[NPR]] |date=January 6, 2021 |last1=Wise |first1=Alana }}</ref> On January 14, prior to being [[Inauguration of Joe Biden|inaugurated]] as president, Biden announced the $1.9 trillion stimulus package.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Mason|first1=Jeff|last2=Renshaw|first2=Jarrett|date=January 14, 2021|title=Biden unveils plan to pump $1.9 trillion into pandemic-hit economy|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-biden-stimulus/biden-to-unveil-plan-to-pump-19-trillion-into-pandemic-hit-economy-idUSKBN29J1B1|website=Reuters}}</ref>

==Legislative history==

===Negotiations===
[[File:Letter from Senate Republicans to President Biden Concerning COVID-19 relief proposal.pdf|thumb|Letter from Senate GOP to President Biden detailing concerns of the American Rescue Plan]]
Ten Republican senators announced plans to unveil a roughly $600 billion COVID-19 relief package as a counterproposal to President Joe Biden's $1.9 trillion plan meant to force negotiations. The senators, including [[Susan Collins]] of Maine, [[Lisa Murkowski]] of Alaska, [[Mitt Romney]] of Utah and [[Rob Portman]] of Ohio, told Biden in a letter that they devised the plan "in the spirit of bipartisanship and unity" that the President has urged and said they planned to release a full proposal on February 1.<ref>{{Cite web|last1=Collinson|first1=Stephen|title=Analysis: Biden faces presidency-defining dilemma over Republican offer on Covid-19 rescue plan|url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/02/01/politics/joe-biden-coronavirus-congress-republicans-trump/index.html|access-date=February 1, 2021|website=CNN|date=February 2021 }}</ref> On the same day, [[Speaker of the United States House of Representatives|House Speaker]] [[Nancy Pelosi]] and [[Senate Majority Leader]] [[Chuck Schumer]] introduced a [[budget resolution]] co-sponsored by [[Bernie Sanders]] as a step to pass the legislation without support from the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/covid-relief-package-budget-reconciliation-democrats/|work=CBS News|title=Democrats introduce budget resolution, kicking off fast-track process to pass COVID package|date=February 2, 2021|access-date=February 2, 2021|first1=Melissa|last1=Quinn|first2=Jack|last2=Turman}}</ref> The next day, Biden met with Majority Leader Schumer and other [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrats]] regarding the relief package.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Carney |first1=Jordain |title=Schumer vows Democrats 'united' after Biden meeting on coronavirus |url=https://thehill.com/homenews/senate/537210-schumer-vows-democrats-united-after-biden-meeting-on-coronavirus |access-date=February 4, 2021 |work=The Hill |date=February 3, 2021}}</ref>

On February 7, [[United States Secretary of Transportation|Transportation Secretary]] [[Pete Buttigieg]] and [[United States Secretary of the Treasury|Treasury Secretary]] [[Janet Yellen]] expressed support for the stimulus package. Yellen said that the funding would help millions of Americans and rejected concerns the colossal spending could cause inflation.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Shahrigian |first1=Shant |title=Janet Yellen, Pete Buttigieg push $1.9T stimulus package |url=https://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/new-york-elections-government/ny-stimulus-package-push-yellen-buttigieg-20210207-s56s2jckqrf23ncxbhut2jiyhe-story.html |access-date=February 7, 2021 |newspaper=New York Daily News |date=February 7, 2021}}</ref> Yellen also said that the stimulus package would restore full employment by 2022.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Crutsinger |first1=Martin |title=Yellen: Biden's plan could restore full employment by 2022 |url=https://abcnews.go.com/Health/wireStory/yellen-bidens-plan-restore-full-employment-2022-75740963 |website=ABC News |access-date=February 7, 2021 |date=February 7, 2021}}</ref> On February 9, Biden met with [[JPMorgan Chase]] [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] [[Jamie Dimon]] and other CEOs to discuss the stimulus plan, with Yellen and Harris taking part in the meeting.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Stein |first1=Jeff |last2=Werner |first2=Erica |title=Jamie Dimon, other CEOs meet with President Biden at White House as relief plan advances |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/us-policy/2021/02/09/wall-street-ceo-white-house-stimulus/ |access-date=February 10, 2021 |newspaper=The Washington Post |date=February 9, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Schroeder |first1=Robert |title=Biden and Yellen discuss $1.9 trillion COVID relief plan with JPMorgan, Walmart, Gap CEOs |url=https://www.marketwatch.com/story/biden-yellen-to-discuss-1-9-trillion-covid-relief-plan-with-jpmorgan-walmart-gap-ceos-11612885087 |access-date=February 10, 2021 |website=Marketwatch |date=February 9, 2021}}</ref> On February 11, Pelosi said that she expects lawmakers to complete the legislation by the end of February, and for the legislation to be signed into law by March 14.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Pramuk |first1=Jacob |title=Pelosi expects Covid relief will be signed into law before unemployment programs expire |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2021/02/11/covid-stimulus-updates-nancy-pelosi-says-relief-bill-will-pass-by-march.html |website=CNBC |access-date=February 11, 2021 |date=February 11, 2021}}</ref>

On February 16, Biden promoted his stimulus plan in a visit in [[Milwaukee]], [[Wisconsin]] during his first official trip as president. He promoted it via a [[CNN]] townhall meeting with voters.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Mason |first1=Jeff |title=With Trump's impeachment trial over, Biden pushes his agenda in televised town hall |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-biden-idUSKBN2AG13B |website=Reuters |access-date=February 16, 2021 |date=February 16, 2021}}</ref> On February 18, Yellen called for major stimulus checks during an interview on [[CNBC]], and said that stimulus checks would help the economy stage a full recovery.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Cox |first1=Jeff |title=Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen makes push for major stimulus, sees bigger risk in not doing enough |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2021/02/18/treasury-secretary-janet-yellen-makes-push-for-a-big-stimulus-sees-bigger-risk-to-not-doing-enough.html |website=C |access-date=February 20, 2021 |date=February 18, 2021 |quote=Yellen, Janet: "We think it’s very important to have a big package [that] addresses the pain this has caused – 15 million Americans behind on their rent, 24 million adults and 12 million children who don’t have enough to eat, small businesses failing."}}</ref>

===Budget resolution passage===
The [[United States Senate]] voted 50–49 to open debate on the resolution, which would allow [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrats]] to pass the relief package without support from [[Republican Party (United States)|Republicans]] through the process of [[Reconciliation (United States Congress)|reconciliation]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Wasson |first1=Erik |title=Senate Democrats Move to Put Biden Stimulus Plan on Fast Track |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-02-02/senate-democrats-move-to-put-biden-stimulus-plan-on-fast-track |access-date=February 5, 2021 |work=Bloomberg |date=February 2, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Zeballos-Roig|first=Joseph|date=February 2, 2021|title=Senate Democrats take the first step to pass Biden's $1.9 trillion stimulus package on their own as the administration stands by it|work=Business Insider|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/stimulus-senate-democrats-biden-rescue-plan-without-gop-votes-2021-2|access-date=February 2, 2021}}</ref> The [[United States House of Representatives|House]] voted 218–212 to approve the budget resolution.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Elis |first1=Niv |title=House approves budget resolution for COVID-19 package |url=https://thehill.com/policy/finance/537220-house-approves-budget-resolution-for-covid-19-package |access-date=February 4, 2021 |work=The Hill |date=February 3, 2021}}</ref> On February 4, a vote-a-rama<ref>{{cite news |last1=Russonello |first1=Giovanni |title=What's in a Vote-a-Rama? |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2021/03/05/us/politics/vote-a-rama.html |access-date=July 26, 2022 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=March 5, 2021}}</ref> session began, and the Senate introduced amendments to the relief package, including an amendment in a 90–10 vote that would provide direct relief to the restaurant industry.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Fantozzi |first1=Joanna |title=The Senate overwhelmingly passed restaurant relief budget resolution amendment |url=https://www.nrn.com/news/senate-overwhelmingly-passed-restaurant-relief-budget-resolution-amendment |website=nrn.com |date=February 4, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Kapur |first1=Sahil |title=Democrats take new step to fast-tracking Covid relief as Senate 'vote-a-rama' begins |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/congress/democrats-take-new-step-fast-tracking-covid-relief-senate-vote-n1256758 |website=NBC News |access-date=February 5, 2021 |date=February 4, 2021}}</ref> [[Vice President of the United States|Vice President]] [[Kamala Harris]] cast a [[List of tie-breaking votes cast by the vice president of the United States|tie-breaking vote]] as President of the Senate for final Senate passage of the reconciliation bill, sending it to the House approval of the changes, and allowing drafting of the relief bill to begin in the committees.<ref>{{cite news |title=Senate passes key budget bill for COVID-19 relief, with Harris as tiebreaker |url=https://www.latimes.com/world-nation/story/2021-02-05/senate-approves-budget-bill-harris-casts-tiebreaker-vote |work=Los Angeles Times}}</ref> The House approved the resolution 219–209, with [[Jared Golden]] being the sole Democrat to join all Republicans in opposition to the bill due to a preference for a separate vaccine bill instead of the longer reconciliation process.<ref>{{cite news |title=House passes budget resolution, paving way for Biden's COVID-19 relief plan|url=https://thehill.com/homenews/house/537534-house-passes-budget-resolution-paving-way-for-bidens-covid-relief-plan |work=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]|date=February 5, 2021}}</ref>

One of the many non-binding budget amendments in the vote-a-rama session was meant to prohibit people who are [[Illegal immigration to the United States|in the country illegally]] from receiving pandemic relief checks. The non-binding amendments were not likely to have any effect on the final relief bill. The Republican Party used hundreds of non-binding votes in the hours-long vote-a-rama session to send messages. Under current law, undocumented immigrants were already prohibited from receiving pandemic relief checks. The amendment passed with eight Democrats joining all Republicans.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Wingerter |first1=Justin |title=Sen. John Hickenlooper frustrates immigration activists with vote to block some from stimulus checks |url=https://www.denverpost.com/2021/02/04/john-hickenlooper-immigration-us-senate/ |access-date=February 5, 2021 |work=The Denver Post |date=February 4, 2021}}</ref> The amendment received criticism from progressive immigration activist [[Greisa Martínez Rosas]] and Senator [[Mazie Hirono]] (D-[[Hawaii|HI]]).<ref>{{cite web |last1=Everett |first1=Burgett |last2=Levine |first2=Marianne |title=Dems split as progressives rage over immigration vote |url=https://www.politico.com/news/2021/02/08/democrats-progressive-immigration-stimulus-467673 |website=Politico |date=February 8, 2021 |quote=Hirono, Mazie: There are undocumented people who pay taxes. … They also have children who are Americans. So they should get those checks. I don’t agree with them. That’s what I make of it.}}</ref> The [[White House]] later stated that it would continue to support legislation that would give all otherwise eligible individuals with [[Social Security number|social security numbers]] stimulus checks.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Carrasquillo |first1=Adrian |title=White House Confirms Support for Stimulus Checks for Citizens Born to Undocumented Immigrants |url=https://www.newsweek.com/white-house-confirms-support-stimulus-checks-citizens-born-undocumented-immigrants-1567997 |website=Newsweek |access-date=February 10, 2021 |date=February 9, 2021}}</ref>

===Budget reconciliation passage===
[[File:0 ARPA 2021 Infographic.png|thumb|right|330px|American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 - Infographic]]
On February 8, a draft of the $1.9 trillion stimulus legislation was released by the [[United States House Committee on Financial Services|Financial Services]] and [[United States House Committee on Education and Labor|Education and Labor]] committees.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Davison |first1=Laura |last2=Wasson |first2=Erik |title=House Democrats Unveil First Draft of Stimulus-Bill Measures |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-02-08/house-democrats-unveil-first-draft-of-stimulus-bill-measures |website=Bloomberg.com |date=February 8, 2021 |access-date=February 8, 2021}}</ref> On February 11, the [[United States House Committee on Ways and Means|House Ways and Means Committee]] advanced a portion of the $1.9 trillion relief package.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Jagoda |first1=Naomi |title=House panel advances portion of relief package that includes $1,400 checks |url=https://thehill.com/policy/finance/538524-house-panel-advances-portion-of-relief-package-that-includes-1400-checks |access-date=February 11, 2021 |work=The Hill |date=February 11, 2021}}</ref> The legislation was also approved by several other House committees such as the [[United States House Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure|Transportation and Infrastructure]], [[United States House Committee on Small Business|Small Business]], and [[United States House Committee on Veterans' Affairs|House Veterans Affairs]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2021/02/12/covid-stimulus-update-house-advances-checks-unemployment-boost.html |title=House advances $1,400 payments, unemployment boost as part of Covid relief plan |last=Pramuck |first=Jacob |date=February 12, 2021 |website=CNBC}}</ref>

On February 19, the full text of the bill was released. Senate Majority Leader [[Chuck Schumer]] said that the Senate would pass the bill before March 14.<ref>{{cite magazine|last=Solender|first=Andrew|date=February 19, 2021|title=Schumer Predicts Biden Will Sign Stimulus Before March 14 Unemployment Deadline|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/andrewsolender/2021/02/19/schumer-predicts-biden-will-sign-stimulus-before-march-14-unemployment-deadline/?sh=29e48828f4f8|website=Forbes|access-date=February 19, 2021}}</ref>  On March 4, Schumer introduced the Senate version of the bill on the floor, which had a few changes to the House bill. ====Minimum wage provision====
{{See also|Minimum wage in the United States}}
President Biden doubted that his desire to increase the federal [[Minimum wage in the United States|minimum wage]] to $15 an hour would be included in the final coronavirus relief package.<ref>{{Cite web|date=February 5, 2021|title=Biden wants fast COVID aid, but minimum wage hike in doubt|url=https://apnews.com/article/senate-ok-fast-track-coronavirus-aid-c497b8cda93486d9f0a09abb88235291|access-date=February 7, 2021|work=Associated Press}}</ref><ref name="Levine 2021">{{Cite web|last=Levine|first=Marianne|title=Biden casts doubt on $15 minimum wage hike in Covid relief package|url=https://www.politico.com/news/2021/02/05/biden-minimum-wage-increase-466400|access-date=February 7, 2021|website=Politico|date=February 5, 2021 |language=en}}</ref> Biden predicted that Senate rules for budget reconciliation would prevent the increase from going forward. While recent polling indicates that support for increasing the minimum wage to $15 an hour ranges from 53 to 60%,<ref>{{Cite web|last=Rakich|first=Nathaniel|title=What Americans Think About The Minimum Wage And Their Governors|url= https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/what-americans-think-about-the-minimum-wage-and-their-governors/|access-date=March 5, 2021|website=FiveThirtyEight|date=March 5, 2021|language=en-US}}</ref> Democratic Senators [[Joe Manchin]] and [[Kyrsten Sinema]] opposed this provision and threatened to derail the bill over this issue.<ref name="Levine 2021" />

On February 25, the day before the full House vote, the [[Parliamentarian of the United States Senate|Senate Parliamentarian]] [[Elizabeth MacDonough]] ruled that the proposal to add the minimum wage provision to the stimulus bill was not compatible with the Senate's budget reconciliation process. Pelosi stated later that day that the House would still approve the bill with the minimum wage raise, although it would have to be amended out in the final Senate bill to comply with the parliamentarian's ruling.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Senate Can't Vote On $15 Minimum Wage, Parliamentarian Rules|url=https://www.npr.org/2021/02/25/970637190/senate-cant-vote-on-15-minimum-wage-parliamentarian-rules|access-date=February 26, 2021|website=NPR.org|language=en}}</ref> Progressive Democrats and liberal groups urged Harris to overrule MacDonough (which she has the constitutional power to do as [[President of the United States Senate|president of the Senate]]) or for Senate Democratic leadership to replace her (which the Republicans did once before, firing [[Robert Dove]] in 2001 after he made a series of rulings blocking tax cuts from being considered under the 51-vote budget reconciliation process); however, neither course was taken.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.newsweek.com/15-minimum-wage-will-kamala-harris-overrule-senate-parliamentarian-1572242|title=On $15 minimum wage, will Kamala Harris overrule the Senate parliamentarian?|date=February 25, 2021|website=Newsweek}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/kamala-harris-political-pressures/2021/03/06/40fe33c4-7d0e-11eb-85cd-9b7fa90c8873_story.html|title=Harris caught between a restless base and a traditionalist Biden|newspaper=Washington Post|date=March 6, 2021|author=Sean Sullivan and Cleve R. Wootson Jr.}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/nation/2021/02/26/senate-parliamentarian-minimum-wage-overrule/|title=Some Democrats want to fire the Senate parliamentarian who scuttled $15 minimum-wage plans. It's been done once before.|date=February 26, 2021|first=Katie|last=Shepherd|newspaper=Washington Post}}</ref> On March 5, eight members of the [[Senate Democratic Caucus|Senate Democratic caucus]] joined all 50 Republican Senators to reject an amendment raised by Senator [[Bernie Sanders|Sanders]] to increase the minimum wage to $15 in the bill.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/bernie-sanders-minmum-wage-senate-vote-b1813158.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210305170618/https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/bernie-sanders-minmum-wage-senate-vote-b1813158.html |archive-date=March 5, 2021 |url-access=limited |url-status=live|title=Senate rejects Sanders proposal for $15 minimum wage in Covid relief package|date=March 5, 2021|website=The Independent}}</ref>

In a budget analysis released in February 2021, the [[Congressional Budget Office]] found that increasing the minimum wage to $15 would lift 900,000 people out of poverty and cumulatively raise the wage of all affected people by $333 billion, but also could increase the cumulative budget deficit, over the next decade, to $54 billion (and add $16 billion in interest costs) and reduce employment by 0.9% (1.4 million jobs) over four years.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Morath|first1=Eric|date=February 8, 2021|title=$15 Minimum Wage Would Cut Employment, Reduce Poverty, CBO Study Finds|work=The Wall Street Journal|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/15-minimum-wage-would-cost-1-4-million-workers-jobs-lift-900-000-from-poverty-cbo-study-finds-11612800875|access-date=February 8, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=The Budgetary Effects of the Raise the Wage Act of 2021|publisher=Congressional Budget Office|url=https://www.cbo.gov/system/files/2021-02/56975-Minimum-Wage.pdf|date=February 2021}}</ref>

Republican Senators [[Mitt Romney]] and [[Tom Cotton]] introduced their own bill, which would raise the minimum wage to $10, phasing in gradually to 2025. The minimum wage would biennially rise with inflation, indexed to the chained [[consumer price index]]. Businesses would also be required to use the [[E-Verify]] system so to ensure that workers paid the higher wages are legal immigrants and eligible to work. Adult workers would have to provide a photo ID, states would be incentivized to share driver's-license data with the system, and the federal government would make more of an effort to block or suspend misused Social Security numbers.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Gregorian |first1=Dareh |title=GOP Sens. Romney, Cotton to propose minimum wage hike coupled with immigration enforcement |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/congress/gop-senator-propose-minimum-wage-hike-coupled-immigration-enforcement-n1258015 |website=NBC News |access-date=February 17, 2021 |date=February 16, 2021}}</ref>

==Key elements==
[[File:American Rescue Plan explained.ogg|thumb|A video from the Biden Administration promoting the American Rescue Plan.]] The Act allocated $60 billion to counties and $10 billion for a Coronavirus Capital Projects Fund.<ref name=StateLocal/> (The bill initially passed by the House would have instead allocated $65 billion to counties and $65 billion to municipalities; rather, the Senate formula was adopted).<ref name=StateLocal/> Key elements and provisions of the Act include:

===Employment===
* [[Unemployment extension|Extending expanded unemployment benefits]] with a $300 weekly supplement through [[Labor Day]] (September 6, 2021), preventing benefits from expiring on March 31, 2021.<ref name=Cochrane>Emily Cochrane, [https://www.nytimes.com/2021/03/06/us/politics/biden-stimulus-plan.html Divided Senate Passes Biden's Pandemic Aid Plan], ''New York Times'' (March 6, 2021).</ref><ref name="Tankersley 2021" />
** Most Democrats favored a higher unemployment benefit amount. The version of the bill initially passed by the House provided for a $400 weekly supplement. Also, some favored continuing the benefits through early October 2021; however, the final bill contained a scaled-back provision at the insistence of Senator [[Joe Manchin]] of [[West Virginia]] and other moderate Senate Democrats.<ref name=Cochrane/><ref name=SenatePassageBill>Tony Romm, Jeff Stein and Erica Werner, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/us-policy/2021/03/06/biden-stimulus-covid-relief/ Senate passes Biden's $1.9 trillion coronavirus relief bill after voting overnight on amendments, sends measure back to House], ''Washington Post'' (March 6, 2021).</ref><ref name="Luhby 2021">Tami Luhby & Katie Lobosco, [https://www.cnn.com/2021/03/04/politics/senate-stimulus-package-what-to-expect-guide/index.html A guide to what you can expect to get from the $1.9 trillion Senate stimulus], CNN (March 6, 2021).</ref>
*The Act made the first $10,200 in unemployment benefits for 2020 non-taxable for households with incomes below $150,000, thus avoiding the risk of many workers incurring surprise federal tax liability.<ref name="Zhou 2021"/>
*The Act provided for $1,400 direct economic stimulus payments to individuals.<ref name="Tankersley 2021" /><ref name=SenatePassageBill/>
**Under pressure from Manchin, Biden agreed to have the direct payments phase out for high-income taxpayers, including some who received stimulus checks in previous stimulus rounds.<ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2021/03/03/biden-limits-eligibility-stimulus-payments-under-pressure-moderate-senate-democrats/ Biden limits eligibility for stimulus payments under pressure from moderate Senate Democrats], ''Washington Post'' (March 3, 2021).</ref><ref name="Zhou 2021">Li Zhou & Emily Stewart, [https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2021/3/6/22315536/stimulus-package-passes-checks-unemployment The Senate just passed the $1.9 trillion stimulus package. Here's what in it.], ''Vox'' (March 6, 2021).</ref> The stimulus benefit began to phase out for individual taxpayers making $75,000, single parents making $112,500, and [[Filing status|couples]] making $150,000. Taxpayers whose income exceeded certain amounts ($80,000 for individuals, $120,000 for single parents, and $160,000 for households) received no stimulus payments.<ref name=Cochrane/> (House Democrats and Biden had favored less stringent caps; the bill initially passed by the House set income caps at $100,000 for individuals and $200,000 for couples).<ref name="Luhby 2021"/>
*Unlike in past rounds of stimulus payments, otherwise eligible adult dependents received payments.<ref name="Zhou 2021"/> Such dependents included college students,<ref name="Zhou 2021"/> [[Supplemental Security Income|SSI]] recipients, and [[Social Security Disability Insurance|SSDI]] recipients.<ref>[https://www.cnet.com/personal-finance/more-than-stimulus-checks-all-the-tax-breaks-parents-and-retirees-should-know/ More than stimulus checks: All the tax breaks parents and retirees should know], ''CNET'' (March 5, 2021).</ref>
*The Act granted emergency paid leave to over 100 million Americans.<ref name="Tankersley 2021" />
*The Act provided a [[tax credit]] through October 1, 2021, to employers who chose to offer paid sick leave and paid family leave benefits. However, the Act did not require employers to provide the benefit, as Biden had initially proposed to do.<ref name="Luhby 2021"/>
*The Act extended a 15% increase in [[Food Stamp Program|food stamp]] benefits. The increase, which was passed in previous rounds of stimulus legislation, was set to expire at the end of June 2021; the Act extended it through September 2021).<ref name="Luhby 2021"/>

===Tax provisions===
*Expands the [[Child tax credit (United States)|child tax credit]]<ref name="Zhou 2021"/> from $2,000 per child, by allowing qualifying families to offset, for the 2021 tax year, $3,000 per child up to age 17 and $3,600 per child under age 6.<ref name="Zhou 2021"/><ref name="Luhby 2021"/> The bill expanded the credit to families with very low incomes or no taxable income who did not previously qualify because of the minimum income requirement, while the size of the benefit will gradually diminish for single filers earning more than $75,000 per year, or married couples making more than $150,000 a year.<ref name="Lieber 2021"/> Additionally, this credit is now fully refundable, and half of the benefit can be sent out to eligible households in 2021 in the form of monthly payments of $250-$300 per child. [[United States Senate|Senator]] [[Mitt Romney]] of [[Utah]] introduced a similar bill four days earlier, but did not vote in favor of the bill.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Higgins |first1=Tucker |title=Democrats unveil one-year plan to send up to $3,600 per child to households |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2021/02/08/democrats-want-to-send-up-to-3600-per-child-to-households.html |website=CNBC |access-date=February 9, 2021 |date=February 8, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.senate.gov/legislative/LIS/roll_call_lists/roll_call_vote_cfm.cfm?congress=117&session=1&vote=00110L|title = U.S. Senate: U.S. Senate Roll Call Votes 117th Congress - 1st Session}}</ref>
*Expands the [[child and dependent care credit]] by making the credit fully refundable and increasing the maximum benefit to $4,000 for one eligible individual and $8,000 for two or more eligible individuals.<ref name="Lieber 2021"/> Additionally, the value of this credit will now be based on 50% of the value of eligible expenses. The income limit for receiving this credit is also increased to $125,000 for households. These changes are also for 2021 only.
*Expands the [[earned income tax credit]] by removing the upper age limit and lowering the lower age limit to 19. The maximum benefit for adults not claiming a qualifying child will also be increased to $1,502. These provisions are for 2021 only. A permanent change was made to raise the limit on investment income from $3,650 to $10,000, furthermore indexed by inflation; and to allow adults with children who do not qualify to claim the credit, to claim it only for themselves.<ref name="Lieber 2021">{{cite news |last1=Lieber |first1=Ron |last2=Bernard |first2=Tara |title=F.A.Q. on Stimulus, Unemployment and Tax Rebates |work=The New York Times |date=March 6, 2021 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/live/2021/03/06/business/stimulus-check-plan-details#how-does-this-change-the-child-tax-credit |access-date=March 12, 2021}}</ref>
*Forgiven [[student loan debt]] is made tax-free, should Biden or Congress decide to cancel any debt.<ref name=Murakami/><ref>Emily Stewart, [https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2021/3/8/22319784/student-loan-debt-stimulus-bill What the Covid-19 relief bill does for student loan forgiveness, explained], ''Vox'' (March 8, 2021).</ref>
* Reduction of reporting requirement threshold ([[Form 1099-K|1099-K]]) for third party settlement organizations (e.g. PayPal) from over $20,000 and 200 transactions to over $600 and no minimum number of transaction, effective from tax year 2022. This is expected to impact [[gig worker]]s, [[Independent contracting in the United States|independent contractors]], casual [[eBay]] sellers, among others. This amendment is projected to generate $8.4 billion over the next decade.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Gig workers could end up losers in Covid relief bill|url=https://www.politico.com/news/2021/03/05/gig-workers-coronavirus-relief-bill-losers-473902|access-date=March 11, 2021|website=POLITICO|date=March 5, 2021 |language=en}}</ref>
*Three tax increases on large corporations and wealthy individuals, collectively raising $60 billion in revenue.<ref name=Faler>Brian Faler, [https://www.politico.com/news/2021/03/10/covid-relief-bill-tax-hikes-475051 A $60 billion surprise in the Covid relief bill: Tax hikes], ''Politico'' (March 10, 2021).</ref> These are:

==Impact==
The bill's economic-relief provisions were overwhelmingly geared toward low-income and middle-class Americans, who received the direct payments, the bill's expansion of low-income tax credits, child-care subsidies, expanded health-insurance access, extension of expanded unemployment benefits, food stamps, and rental assistance programs.<ref name=Tankersley>Jim Tankersley, [https://www.nytimes.com/2021/03/06/business/biden-economy.html To Juice the Economy, Biden Bets on the Poor], ''New York Times'' (March 6, 2021).</ref> The bill contains little direct aid to high income-earners, who largely retained their jobs during the COVID-19 economic shock and bolstered their savings.<ref name=Tankersley/> Biden's administration crafted the plan in part because economic aid to lower-income and middle-income Americans (who are more likely to immediately spend funds on bills, groceries, and housing costs to avoid eviction or foreclosure) is more likely to stimulate the U.S. economy than aid to higher-earners (who are more likely to save the money).<ref name=Tankersley/> The [[Institute on Taxation and Economic Policy]] predicted that the stimulus bill's direct payments, [[Child tax credit (United States)|child tax credit]] expansion, and [[earned income tax credit]] expansion would boost the income of the poorest one-fifth of Americans by nearly $3,590.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Picchi |first1=Aimee |title=Stimulus bill would boost incomes of poorest Americans by nearly $4,000 |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/stimulus-check-bill-income-poorest-americans/ |website=CBS News |access-date=February 14, 2021 |date=February 12, 2021}}</ref> The [[Congressional Budget Office]] estimated that the bill's increase in health insurance subsidies would lead to 1.3 million previously uninsured Americans gaining [[Health insurance coverage in the United States|health insurance coverage]].<ref>Paige Winfield Cunningham, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2021/03/03/health-202-buried-biden-stimulus-plan-is-29-percent-spending-hike-obamacare-subsidies/ The Health 202: Buried in Biden's stimulus plan is a 29 percent spending hike in Obamacare subsidies], ''The Washington Post'' (March 3, 2021).</ref> A 2022 study from the [[Brookings Institution]] found mixed results for some of the bill's economic development funding.<ref name="Brookings BBBRC paper">{{cite web |last1=Parilla|first1=Joseph|last2=Haskins|first2=Glencora|last3=Muro|first3=Mark| title=The future of place-based economic policy: Early insights from the Build Back Better Regional Challenge | website=Brookings | date=November 17, 2022 | url=https://www.brookings.edu/articles/the-future-of-place-based-economic-policy-early-insights-from-the-build-back-better-regional-challenge/ | access-date=May 17, 2024}}</ref>

The [[Tax Policy Center]] wrote that, for households making under $25,000, the bill would cut their taxes by an average of $2,800, which would boost their after-tax income by 20%. Additionally, low-income households with children would see an average tax cut of about $7,700, and this would boost their after-tax income by 35%. Middle-income households will also see an average tax cut of about $3,350, and this would increase their after-tax income by 5.5%. Overall, about 70% of the bill's tax benefits will go to households making under $91,000.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Gleckman |first1=Howard |title=Pandemic Bill Would Cut Taxes by An Average of $3,000, With Most Relief Going to Low- And Middle-Income Households |url=https://www.taxpolicycenter.org/taxvox/pandemic-bill-would-cut-taxes-average-3000-most-relief-going-low-and-middle-income-households |website=Tax Policy Center |date=March 8, 2021 |access-date=March 8, 2021}}</ref>

=== Inflationary impact ===
{{See also|2021–2023 inflation surge}}

A March 2022 study released by the [[Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco]] estimated that U.S. fiscal support measures designed to counteract the severity of the pandemic's economic effect (among them, the American Rescue Plan and the 2020 [[CARES Act]]) may have raised core inflation about 3 percentage points by the end of 2021, noting that this estimate falls "in the upper range of findings from other recent research". At the same time, the study notes that these measures may have prevented "outright deflation and slower economic growth, the consequences of which would have been harder to manage".<ref>{{Cite news |date=March 29, 2022 |title=San Francisco Fed Paper Ties Some of the Inflation Surge to Fiscal Aid |language=en-US |work=Wall Street Journal |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/san-francisco-fed-paper-ties-some-of-the-inflation-surge-to-fiscal-aid-11648589868 |access-date=April 25, 2022 |issn=0099-9660}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Jordà |first=Òscar |date=March 28, 2022 |title=Why Is U.S. Inflation Higher than in Other Countries? |url=https://www.frbsf.org/wp-content/uploads/sites/4/el2022-07.pdf |journal=FRBSF Economic Letter}}</ref> The study estimates the effect on inflation from the aggregate of all U.S. fiscal support measures and does not give estimates for the effects of individual measures.

President [[Joe Biden]] advocated for fast-tracking the stimulus package with optimally bipartisan support. In early February 2021, Biden criticized Republicans for not seeking a bipartisan compromise on a final aid bill, and said the Republicans were wilfully obstructing his proposal.<ref name="White House remarks">{{Cite web|date=February 5, 2021|title=Remarks by President Biden on the State of the Economy and the Need for the American Rescue Plan|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/speeches-remarks/2021/02/05/remarks-by-president-biden-on-the-state-of-the-economy-and-the-need-for-the-american-rescue-plan/|access-date=February 10, 2021|website=The White House|language=en-US}}</ref> At the time, Biden signaled openness to passing the legislation without any support from congressional Republicans.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Chalfant|first1=Morgan|last2=Samuels|first2=Brett|date=February 5, 2021|title=Biden signals he'll move forward on COVID-19 relief without GOP|work=The Hill|url=https://thehill.com/homenews/administration/537544-biden-signals-hell-move-forward-on-covid-19-relief-without-gop}}</ref> Biden stated that he could not, "in good conscience," make concessions to Republicans who he said propose to either "do nothing or not enough" as Republicans complain Biden is forsaking his promises on bipartisanship and unity.<ref name="White House remarks" /> Furthermore, Biden noted that "[a]ll of a sudden, many of them have rediscovered fiscal restraint and the concern for the deficits" in reference to the [[First presidency of Donald Trump|Trump administrations]] increase in the [[National debt of the United States|national debt]] following expansive [[Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017|tax cuts]] and [[CARES Act|COVID-19 mitigation spending]] .<ref name="White House remarks" />

===Others===
Republican mayors such as [[Jerry Dyer]] of [[Fresno, California]], [[Francis Suarez]] of [[Miami]], [[David Holt (politician)|David Holt]] of [[Oklahoma City]], and [[Betsy Price]] of [[Fort Worth, Texas]], expressed their support for the plan. Dyer told the [[The Washington Post|''Washington Post'']] that "It's not a Republican issue or a Democrat issue. It's a public health issue. It's an economic issue. And it's a public safety issue."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Villarreal |first1=Daniel |title='Way Overdue': Biden's $1.9 Tn Stimulus Plan Wins Support Among GOP Leaders Outside D.C. |url=https://www.newsweek.com/way-overdue-bidens-19-tn-stimulus-plan-wins-support-among-gop-leaders-outside-dc-1569451 |website=Newsweek |access-date=February 21, 2021 |date=February 15, 2021}}</ref>

Over 150 [[Chief executive officer|CEOs]] of major companies expressed support for the Biden stimulus plan in a letter and urged Congress to pass it.<ref>{{cite web|last1=DeNisco Rayome|first1=Alison|date=February 24, 2021|title=CEOs from Google, Zoom and over 150 companies urge Congress to pass Biden stimulus plan|url=https://www.cnet.com/news/ceos-from-google-zoom-and-over-150-companies-urge-congress-to-pass-biden-stimulus-plan/|access-date=February 24, 2021|website=CNET}}</ref>

A broad range of advocacy and interest groups praised the bill, including local government groups ([[National Association of Counties]] and [[U.S. Conference of Mayors]]); business associations ([[National Farmers Union (United States)|National Farmers Union]], [[Airlines for America]], [[National Association of Realtors]], [[National Restaurant Association]], [[Small Business Majority]]); education organizations (the [[American Council on Education]], [[American Federation of Teachers]], [[National Education Association]], [[National School Boards Association]]), organized labor (the [[AFL–CIO]] and [[AFSCME]]); healthcare organizations ([[American Academy of Pediatrics]], [[Association of State and Territorial Health Officials]], [[National Nurses United]]), the [[American Public Transportation Association]], and the civil rights group [[UnidosUS]].<ref name=InterestGroups>Alicia Parlapiano, [https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2021/03/06/upshot/covid-stimulus-industry-groups.html What 27 Special Interest Groups Said About the Stimulus Bill], ''New York Times'' (March 7, 2021).</ref> [[Feeding America]], the American Hotel & Lodging Association, the Main Street Alliance, the U.S. Travel Association, the [[American Hospital Association]], the [[Association of American Medical Colleges]], and the National Council of Nonprofits praised the bill, but said that additional relief would be necessary.<ref name=InterestGroups/> The [[Business Roundtable]], [[U.S. Chamber of Commerce]], and [[Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget]] called for a smaller and more targeted package.<ref name=InterestGroups/>

Several observers have noted that the stimulus greatly increases the role of the government in fighting poverty in the United States, to an extent not seen since Lyndon Johnson's [[Great Society]] in the 1960s; accordingly some have seen it as evidence that the United States is moving towards [[social democracy]] and away from the "[[Speeches and debates of Ronald Reagan|government is the problem]]" consensus in place since the 1980s.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ft.com/content/12c7608f-b15c-4109-971c-8946e72602cf|title=Joe Biden and the new era of big government|first1=James|last1=Politi|first2=Lauren|last2=Fedor|first3=Taylor Nicole|last3=Rogers|newspaper=Financial Times|date=March 12, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.politico.com/news/magazine/2021/03/10/congress-covid-relief-stimulus-welfare-cash-benefits-474916|title=Congress Ends Welfare Reform as We Know It |website=[[Politico]]|date=March 10, 2021 }}</ref>

[[Dave Yost]], the Republican [[Ohio Attorney General]], sued the Biden administration over the provision of the Act that creates a $350 billion fund to help state and local governments pay [[first responder]]s and other COVID-19-related expenses. The Act provides that a state cannot use federal aid money to offset net revenues lost if a state chooses to implement new state tax cuts. Yost's suit claims that this limitation coerces states and infringes on their "sovereign authority to set state tax policy."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/us-policy/2021/03/17/stimulus-lawsuit-gop-ohio-attorney-general/|newspaper=Washington Post|title=Ohio attorney general sues Biden administration over $1.9 trillion stimulus|first=Tony|last=Romm|date=March 17, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.dispatch.com/story/news/politics/state/2021/03/17/ohio-attorney-general-dave-yost-lawsuit-coronavirus-tax-cut-mandate/4734960001/|newspaper=Columbus Dispatch|title=Ohio Attorney General Dave Yost sues feds over restrictions on coronavirus relief aid|first=Marc|last=Kovac|date=March 18, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|last=Yost|first=Dave|author-link=Dave Yost|date=March 24, 2021 |title=The Biden Administration Is Coercing the States. Ohio Is Fighting Back |work=[[National Review]]|url=https://www.nationalreview.com/2021/03/the-biden-administration-is-coercing-the-states-ohio-is-fighting-back/ |access-date=March 24, 2021}}</ref>

Clinton Administration Treasury Secretary and Harvard University President [[Lawrence Summers]] called the bill "the least responsible macroeconomic policy we've had in the last 40 years," arguing the law would lead to substantial inflation (and possibly a recession, if the Federal Reserve responded by raising interest rates).<ref>{{Cite web|date=March 20, 2021|title=Larry Summers blasts $1.9 T stimulus as 'least responsible' economic policy in 40 years|url=https://thehill.com/policy/finance/544188-larry-summers-blasts-least-responsible-economic-policy-in-40-years}}</ref> Later data would show a large surge in inflation.<ref>{{Cite web|date=July 17, 2021|title=Former Treasury secretary breaks down rising inflation|website=[[CNN]]|url=https://www.cnn.com/videos/tv/2021/07/17/consumer-prices-surge-is-it-time-to-worry-about-inflation.cnn}}</ref> Although the importance of the law in causing this has been disputed, price increases rose to the highest levels in 40 years, as Summers had argued.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://nypost.com/2022/01/12/now-bidens-given-america-the-worst-inflation-in-40-years/|title=Now Biden's given America the worst inflation in 40 years|date=January 13, 2022}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/2022/04/14/business/larry-summers-was-right-inflation-lets-hope-his-recession-forecast-is-wrong/|title = Larry Summers was right on inflation. Let's hope his recession forecast is wrong. - the Boston Globe|website = [[The Boston Globe]]}}</ref>
